authorsByline: Kory Woods | kwoods@mlive.com, Kory Woods, kwoods3
title: Lions QB gives himself brutal rating after performance versus Chargers
description: Lions quarterback Hendon Hooker was blunt when asked to rate his performance against the Chargers last week.
content:
Los Angeles Chargers linebacker Tre'Mon Morris-Brash, left, sacksDetroit Lions quarterback Hendon Hooker, right, in the second half of the Pro Football Hall of Fame NFL preseason game Thursday, July 31, 2025, in Canton, Ohio. (AP Photo/David Richard) AP

ALLEN PARK -- In a competition with Kyle Allen to back up Jared Goff, Lions quarterback Hendon Hooker knows his performance in last Thursday’s Hall of Fame Game against the Chargers didn’t meet the mark.

“A zero out of 10,” Hooker told reporters when asked to rate his showing. “It wasn’t to my standards or the team’s standards of just being productive and controlling the huddle and making plays.”

Hooker started the second half in Canton, completing 3 of 6 passes for 18 yards and an interception. He was sacked twice and ran three times for nine yards.

It was hardly the showing Hooker wanted as he looks to solidify himself as Detroit’s No. 2 quarterback. This opportunity previously belonged to Teddy Bridgewater in recent years.

Still, it’s fair to wonder what Hooker might have done with a full first-half workload, like the one Allen received.

Allen went 9 of 14 for 91 yards and two interceptions, both of which came in the opening quarter.

“Offensively, you like to see – just to get down there in that red zone a little bit more,” Lions head coach Dan Campbell said. “And that requires not turning the ball over, as we know, converting on first downs, but that would be the big thing. Whereas joint practices, you know, you’re going to get those. You’re going to get plenty of your base reps, red zones, third downs, all of those.”

When the Lions face the Atlanta Falcons this Friday at Mercedes-Benz Stadium -- their second of four preseason games -- Hooker will start the first half. Allen will take over in the second.

“Just play the next play, have short-term memory, and just continue to motivate my teammates,” Hooker said about overcoming last week’s play. “That’s what I’m here to do -- push my troops down the field and put the ball into the end zone.”

Hooker isn’t offering excuses for the outing. He said the focus remains on execution, and he understands how crucial each snap is -- whether it’s his decision-making or delivery from the pocket.

Even with the starting nod this week, his mindset won’t change.

“(I’ll) prepare the same way,” Hooker said. “I’ll play with that same confidence and swagger and have fun.”
summary: Lions quarterback Hendon Hooker has given himself a zero out of 10 rating after his performance in the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game against the Chargers. Hooker, who started the second half, completed 3 of 6 passes for 18 yards and an interception, was sacked twice and ran three times for nine yards. This performance was not ideal for him as he aims to solidify his position as Detroit's No. 2 quarterback. Despite this, Hooker remains confident and insists his focus remains on execution. He will start the first half of the upcoming Lions game against the Atlanta Falcons, with Kyle Allen taking over in the second.
shortSummary: Detroit Lions quarterback Hendon Hooker criticized his performance in the Hall of Fame Game against the Chargers, while emphasizing execution and motivation as he seeks to cement his position as No.2 quarterback.

ALLEN PARK -- A pair of former Detroit Lions saw their NFL journeys head in opposite directions this week as teams continue to shuffle rosters during training camp.
The Indianapolis Colts released cornerback Corey Ballentine after just one week of camp. Ballentine signed a one-year, $1.337 million deal this offseason, including $482,500 guaranteed. The Colts re-signed veteran nickelback Chris Lammons in a corresponding move.
Indianapolis had waived Lammons in January.
In a separate transaction, the Minnesota Vikings signed former Lions offensive lineman Matt Nelson. They waived rookie defensive lineman Alexander Williams with an injury designation.
Ballentine, 29, was a sixth-round pick by the New York Giants in 2019 and has now spent time with seven NFL teams. That includes a brief stint in Detroit after the Lions claimed him off waivers from the New York Jets in September 2021.
He appeared in four games for the Lions, primarily contributing on special teams, where he played 48 snaps and returned four kicks for 94 yards. Ballentine has also had stops in Atlanta, Arizona, and Green Bay.
Nelson, also 29, joined the Lions in 2019 as an undrafted free agent out of Iowa, where he played defensive line. Detroit converted him to offensive tackle, and he went on to appear in 43 games (14 starts) from 2020-23. 11 of those starts came during the 2021 season, when the Lions won just three games during Dan Campbell’s first season as head coach.
Nelson mainly lined up at right tackle and was frequently used as an extra lineman in heavy personnel packages.

ALLEN PARK -- In a game full of dark spots, Detroit Lions offensive lineman Colby Sorsdal was one of the few bright ones coming out of Thursday’s 34-7 loss to the Los Angeles Chargers.
Sorsdal, who’s entering his third NFL season, has had an up-and-down tenure in Detroit, with fans questioning if the former William & Mary standout will reach his full potential and be a key piece on the offensive line.
Of players with at least 10 snaps, Pro Football Focus had Sorsdal as one of the five highest-graded offensive players with a 74.2. Playing 24 snaps (45%) during the Hall of Fame game, Sorsdal showed promise adjusting to life at guard and was pretty solid in the run game.
When speaking with MLive, Sorsdal credited Lions offensive line coach and run game coordinator Hank Fraley for his growth.
“The continuity is awesome with Hank,” Sorsdal said. “He really gets the guys going in our run games, humming, and I feel like that’s our bread and butter. So we’re going to keep it rolling, and it’s feeling great right now.”
Sorsdal is one of the Lions’ most versatile offensive linemen, having been shifted around in many spots during the past few seasons, allowing the coaching staff to see where his best fit is.
Because of how the coaching staff has moved him around, Sorsdal shared the difficulties of compartmentalization and having to share the memory, likened to a goldfish.
“I’m not going to lie. It’s difficult, but I’m up for the challenge just like any of us are,” Sorsdal said. “So it’s exciting. You just need something to get out there. So anything I can do to help the team is what I’m willing to do.”
When asked if he has a preference for where the staff chooses to line him up, Sorsdal joked, “Offensive line,” essentially showcasing a willingness to do what is asked of him as long as he is seeing playing time.
With the Lions having several exits from Sorsdal’s unit, specifically the former center Frank Ragnow’s sudden retirement and the departure of offensive lineman Kevin Zeitler, who bolted Detroit for Tennessee, there’s been some concern for how the unit would gel heading into their 2025 campaign.
Similar to Graham Glasgow’s comments from last week, Sorsdal highlighted there are some things that the offensive line needs to “clean up,” specifically from the pass protection.
However, with it still being incredibly early in their training camp, he is confident his unit will be able to make the corrections before the season starts and address the mistakes in the film room.
“We’ve always taken pride, especially just as the offensive line, as the next band up kind of mentality, and with these young cats in there, it’s everybody’s kind of nervous, but man, we’re just like, ‘Hey, let’s roll, man. Go put the pads on, strap it up, and run through somebody’s face.’ So we’re excited, we feel great.”

ALLEN PARK — The Detroit Lions’ first preseason game was about as rocky as it could’ve gone with five turnovers and a 27-point defeat to the Los Angeles Chargers.
However, the result of an exhibition isn’t as key for the Lions as getting to see what their team looks like at this point in training camp.
To that end, the Lions want to see their players in a plethora of game situations during preseason matchups. The first time around, the Lions got some good opportunities, but coach Dan Campbell shared what and where he’d still like to see his team get some live reps.
“I’d like to see more first downs on offense,” Campbell joked during a press conference on Sunday.
“If anything, yeah, you’d like to have felt like you got down in the red zone a little bit more offensively and got some of those reps...And that requires not turning the ball over, as we know, and then converting on first downs. But that would be the big thing.”
The Lions made just one trip to the red zone the entire night and crossed into Chargers territory on four of 10 total drives.
Turnovers and slow offensive play — 1-for-11 on third downs — led to the Lions having few chances to get in those clutch situations in the red zone.
Quarterback Kyle Allen did help guide the Lions to their lone trip to the red zone in the first quarter, converting on a pair of fourth downs before running back Craig Reynolds found the end zone from three yards.
The Lions defense, on the other hand, got to experience quite a lot, with Campbell saying they got to see “a little bit of everything” save for a good two-minute drive.
Particularly after the turnovers, the Chargers had great starting field position, giving the Lions’ defense a handful of drives where they started deep in their own territory.
A fumble on the opening kickoff led to a quick scoring drive, but later in the game the Lions defended three straight plays from their own five-yard line following a muffed punt. The unit forced the Chargers to settle for a chip-shot field goal.
While the game itself became a real let down for Detroit, getting into those different situations out of a practice setting is a real help. The Lions will have three more preseason opportunities, starting with Friday’s road game against the Atlanta Falcons.
